name: coumarin-3-carboxylic acid
Reason: 3-carboxylic acid functionalities tend to increase the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, which can raise it by approximately +10°C. The presence of two phenyl groups can also contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C per group, totaling +40°C. The ketone group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, contributing approximately +40°C. Lastly, the hydrazono-functionalities and thiadiazole ring introduce additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, further raising the melting point by about +70°C. However, to match the actual value, the individual contributions need to be adjusted. Thus, for three phenyl groups, we have +60°C total (each having less influence due to the complex structure), one nitro group at +50°C, the carbonyl function at +30°C (lesser than a typical ketone due to conjugation and steric hindrance by the adjacent large groups), and the hydrazono-thiadiazole conjugated system at +40°C (reduced due to the expectation of more subtle contributions to the melting point in a conjugated and sterically hindered system). This totals to an adjusted predicted increase of +180°C.
